speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then such an environment generates an observation that the agent then integrates together with its prior beliefs in order to infer the hidden states of the environment, which is what we call perception.

text: Then you can use this information to plan ahead and select an action accordingly.

text: And concretely, how the agent side of this works in active inference is so that you specify a probabilistic generative model that contains the hidden states,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: your a priori knowledge or your assumptions about how these hidden states relate to each other, which states may follow upon which states and so on.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In theory, you could also solve the beliefs of the generative model analytically, but that becomes very computationally expensive really quickly or even analytically intractable.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what you do instead is formulate these approximate beliefs, which are supposed to be of a simpler form.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And for example, in your approximate beliefs, you could assume that all hidden variables are independent random variables, which makes the beliefs very easy to calculate, but may not properly capture the temporal dynamics, for example, of your environment.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then you would have pairwise dependencies in these approximate beliefs, which is then called the beta approximation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You may have different approximations for different variables.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Some may vary together.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Others are independent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then you plug in the generative model and your approximate beliefs into the free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02
